issue.title: Add support for list of receivers
issue.body: This change allows Socketshark to facilitate a smooth operating transition from one Redis instance to another. It provides a configuration option for an alternate Redis instance. If present, Socketshark will subscribe to each channel on both instances. This allows publishers to migrate between Redis instances without interrupting clients.

comment.body: @cschams just to make this explicit – since we have to ship this and validate it's doing the right thing by this Wed at the latest (11/23), I'm happy to skip the less important comments & nits. The important comments should be addressed though and you should test these changes thoroughly.

                     # Ping timeout
                     ping.cancel()
                     self.shark.log.warn('redis ping timeout')
+                    self._stop = True
comment.body:
Gotcha. In such case we need to remember (and document somewhere) that, during migrations from one Redis to another, you:
* CANNOT do this:
    1. Have a SocketShark service that's connected to Redis A.
    2. Set up a Redis B.
    3. Make the SocketShark service connect to Redis A & Redis B.
    4. Change other services to start publishing to Redis B.
    5. Shut down Redis A.
        * This would make the whole SocketShark service stop.
* CAN do this:
    1. Same steps 1-4 as above.
    2. Update the SocketShark service to only connect to Redis B.
    3. Shut down Redis A.

Right?

comment.body: AFAICT, [`RedisConnection.wait_closed`](https://github.com/aio-libs/aioredis-py/blob/v1.3.1/aioredis/connection.py#L436-L438) waits till the corresponding Redis connection is closed. If we have N Redis connections, shouldn't we wait for N of them to close? In other words, shouldn't we use `ALL_COMPLETED` vs `FIRST_COMPLETED`?

People could read up on it in libpq's documentation, but I think
having it right there at your fingertips makes it easier to digest.

Add "also" since we're mentioning `TCP_USER_TIMEOUT` for the second time.

Wording tweak (thanks @squeaky-pl!)

Tweak the first 2 paragraphs.

also also changed them to use an 80 char line width.

reveal our final configuration. I also decided to drop the explanation of each
`connect_args` param since people can easily look that up in the docs.

issue.title: ARM Support
issue.body:
We currently run Intel images on ARM. There are two flavors of mysql: [GPL community one with we use currently](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28/images/sha256-e9fee3e714fd69cd2ccfa0c6a141fac0a60f2a02f72d43c0e7055601aaf481b0?context=explore) and [Oracle one which also supports ARM](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28-oracle/images/sha256-39b3c2650e24da10a4cb31f589e4e4aff70f2f732283ccd05390781e19cec5e9?context=explore).

We should investigate if there are any major differences between these images and if there are any drawbacks to running the ARM version of the image locally. It would help us avoid running Rosetta on our M1 Macs.

commits.message:
Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2 (#36)

* Only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled.

This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160,
which fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

* Only test MongoEngine on Python v3.7 and v3.8.

Versions 3.5 and 3.6 are past their EOL already:
https://endoflife.date/python

pull_request.title: Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2
pull_request.body:
This PR makes sure that we only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled via `QuerySet.timeout(False)`. Previously, we were setting `no_cursor_timeout: False` on many operations, some of which started actively rejecting (vs ignoring) this option in MongoDB v4.2. This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160. It fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

Without this fix, e.g. `Document.modify` (which calls PyMongo's `find_one_and_update`) would fails with the following error:
```
mongoengine.errors.OperationError: Update failed (BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field., full error: {'ok': 0.0, 'errmsg': "BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field.", 'code': 51177, 'codeName': 'Location51177'})
```

I also stopped testing Python versions v3.5 and v3.6 in this PR since they are past their EOL already: https://endoflife.date/python

comment.body:
Gotcha. In such case we need to remember (and document somewhere) that, during migrations from one Redis to another, you:
* CANNOT do this:
    1. Have a SocketShark service that's connected to Redis A.
    2. Set up a Redis B.
    3. Make the SocketShark service connect to Redis A & Redis B.
    4. Change other services to start publishing to Redis B.
    5. Shut down Redis A.
        * This would make the whole SocketShark service stop.
* CAN do this:
    1. Same steps 1-4 as above.
    2. Update the SocketShark service to only connect to Redis B.
    3. Shut down Redis A.

Right?

Explain what each of the connection params means in our code.

People could read up on it in libpq's documentation, but I think
having it right there at your fingertips makes it easier to digest.

Add "also" since we're mentioning `TCP_USER_TIMEOUT` for the second time.

Wording tweak (thanks @squeaky-pl!)

Tweak the first 2 paragraphs.

also also changed them to use an 80 char line width.

Move the whole post to 80 char line width.

This commit doesn't contain any other content changes, just formatting.

I cannot really read/edit it in my Vim editor otherwise. Even with text
wrapping, it reads weird.

Title, permalink, updated date, and more wordsmithing.

reorganized the sections somewhat, so that we first tell a story and then
reveal our final configuration. I also decided to drop the explanation of each
`connect_args` param since people can easily look that up in the docs.

issue.title: ARM Support
issue.body:
We currently run Intel images on ARM. There are two flavors of mysql: [GPL community one with we use currently](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28/images/sha256-e9fee3e714fd69cd2ccfa0c6a141fac0a60f2a02f72d43c0e7055601aaf481b0?context=explore) and [Oracle one which also supports ARM](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28-oracle/images/sha256-39b3c2650e24da10a4cb31f589e4e4aff70f2f732283ccd05390781e19cec5e9?context=explore).

We should investigate if there are any major differences between these images and if there are any drawbacks to running the ARM version of the image locally. It would help us avoid running Rosetta on our M1 Macs.

commits.message:
Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2 (#36)

* Only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled.

This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160,
which fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

* Only test MongoEngine on Python v3.7 and v3.8.

Versions 3.5 and 3.6 are past their EOL already:
https://endoflife.date/python

pull_request.title: Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2
pull_request.body:
This PR makes sure that we only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled via `QuerySet.timeout(False)`. Previously, we were setting `no_cursor_timeout: False` on many operations, some of which started actively rejecting (vs ignoring) this option in MongoDB v4.2. This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160. It fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

Without this fix, e.g. `Document.modify` (which calls PyMongo's `find_one_and_update`) would fails with the following error:
```
mongoengine.errors.OperationError: Update failed (BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field., full error: {'ok': 0.0, 'errmsg': "BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field.", 'code': 51177, 'codeName': 'Location51177'})
```

I also stopped testing Python versions v3.5 and v3.6 in this PR since they are past their EOL already: https://endoflife.date/python

pull_request.title: Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2
pull_request.body:
This PR makes sure that we only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled via `QuerySet.timeout(False)`. Previously, we were setting `no_cursor_timeout: False` on many operations, some of which started actively rejecting (vs ignoring) this option in MongoDB v4.2. This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160. It fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

I also stopped testing Python versions v3.5 and v3.6 in this PR since they are past their EOL already: https://endoflife.date/python

issue.title: Add support for list of receivers
issue.body: This change allows Socketshark to facilitate a smooth operating transition from one Redis instance to another. It provides a configuration option for an alternate Redis instance. If present, Socketshark will subscribe to each channel on both instances. This allows publishers to migrate between Redis instances without interrupting clients.

The important comments should be addressed though and you should test these changes thoroughly.

                     # Ping timeout
                     ping.cancel()
                     self.shark.log.warn('redis ping timeout')
+                    self._stop = True
comment.body:
Gotcha. In such case we need to remember (and document somewhere) that, during migrations from one Redis to another, you:
* CANNOT do this:
    1. Have a SocketShark service that's connected to Redis A.
    2. Set up a Redis B.
    3. Make the SocketShark service connect to Redis A & Redis B.
    4. Change other services to start publishing to Redis B.
    5. Shut down Redis A.
        * This would make the whole SocketShark service stop.
* CAN do this:
    1. Same steps 1-4 as above.
    2. Update the SocketShark service to only connect to Redis B.
    3. Shut down Redis A.

Right?

also also changed them to use an 80 char line width.

issue.title: ARM Support
issue.body:
We currently run Intel images on ARM. There are two flavors of mysql: [GPL community one with we use currently](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28/images/sha256-e9fee3e714fd69cd2ccfa0c6a141fac0a60f2a02f72d43c0e7055601aaf481b0?context=explore) and [Oracle one which also supports ARM](https://hub.docker.com/layers/mysql/library/mysql/8.0.28-oracle/images/sha256-39b3c2650e24da10a4cb31f589e4e4aff70f2f732283ccd05390781e19cec5e9?context=explore).

We should investigate if there are any major differences between these images and if there are any drawbacks to running the ARM version of the image locally. It would help us avoid running Rosetta on our M1 Macs.

commits.message:
Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2 (#36)

* Only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled.

This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160,
which fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

* Only test MongoEngine on Python v3.7 and v3.8.

Versions 3.5 and 3.6 are past their EOL already:
https://endoflife.date/python

pull_request.title: Fix our fork of MongoEngine for MongoDB v4.2
pull_request.body:
This PR makes sure that we only set `no_cursor_timeout` if timeout has been explicitly disabled via `QuerySet.timeout(False)`. Previously, we were setting `no_cursor_timeout: False` on many operations, some of which started actively rejecting (vs ignoring) this option in MongoDB v4.2. This is a backport of https://github.com/MongoEngine/mongoengine/pull/2160. It fixes MongoEngine running against MongoDB v4.2.

Without this fix, e.g. `Document.modify` (which calls PyMongo's `find_one_and_update`) would fails with the following error:
```
mongoengine.errors.OperationError: Update failed (BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field., full error: {'ok': 0.0, 'errmsg': "BSON field 'no_cursor_timeout' is an unknown field.", 'code': 51177, 'codeName': 'Location51177'})
```

I also stopped testing Python versions v3.5 and v3.6 in this PR since they are past their EOL already: https://endoflife.date/python
